# Images 

Would you like to have alot of visitors on your website everyday! 
Images can do that, they help make the difference between a normal looking site and a really engaging one.
![images](https://infobeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/featured-image.jpg)

Images can be used to set the tone for a site in less time than it takes to read a description.

### The images we choose should have these specifications :
1. Be relevant
2. Convey information
3. Convey the right mood
4. Be instantly recognisable
5. Fit the color palette
 We can buy these images fron many online companies , and they will have their own copyrights so no on can steal them.

 ### Storing images on your site

 It's better to create a folder to save the images files we will use in our website separated from other files.
Sometimes in the big sites we need to use subfolders inside the images folder so that keep them in a better organization.

### Adding images

To add images to our site we use the `img` elemant which has the two attributes :
1. ***src*** : a relative URL tells the browser where it can find the image file.
2. ***alt*** : if we can't see the image,this gives a short description to describe what's the image talking about.

           `<img src="" alt="">`

### Height and width of the images
`img` element can also have these two attributes to specify it's size :
   `<img src="" alt="" width="" height="">`

After that we should know **where we should place the images in our site** because where an image is placed in the code will affect how it is displayed.

There is many methods to place images :
Aligning them **vertically** : which is an old method and not used today in HTML5 , nowadays we have many alot attractive methods .

 ![alighning images](https://mk0designbombsg12amh.kinstacdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/16.jpeg)

 ### Three rules for creating images

1. Save images in the right format.
2. Save images at the right size.
3. Use the correct resolution.

### Tools to edit and save images
There are several tools you can use to edit and
save images to ensure that they are the right
size, format, and resolution.

We can use the **Adobe photoshop** but it's expensive so as a biggeners we can use another cheaper version called **Photoshop Elements**, also we can use the **online editors** , using the **online extra** which allows us to watch videos to see how we can edit our images and format  them using these applications.

### Image formats
1. GIF
Use GIF or PNG format when saving images with few colors or large areas of the same color.
Also they can be an **animated gif** which show several frames of an image in sequence.

![gif](https://data.whicdn.com/images/296589587/original.gif)


2. JPEG
Whenever we have many different colors in a picture we should use a JPEG

![jpeg](https://www.paintshoppro.com/static/psp/images/pages/seo/ui-screenshot.jpg)


### Image dimentions

The images we use on our website should be saved at the same width and height that we want them to appear on the page, so we should change it's size by decreasing or increasing it , sometimes we need to crop them but keep in mind that it is important not to lose valuable information.

### Image resolution

Images created for the web should be saved at
a **resolution of 72 ppi**. The higher the resolution of the image, the larger the size of the file.

### Vector images 
Vector images is different from bitmap images and
are resolution-independent. Vector images are
commonly created in programs such as Adobe
Illustrator.

When the image is such as a logo, illustration, or diagram), they are created in a vector format.

![vector images](https://i.pinimg.com/originals/f1/aa/e4/f1aae4979c7876aab3f550489ec7e9c3.jpg)

### Transparency
Creating an image that is transparent for the web involves selecting one of two formats:

1. Transparent GIF.
2. PNG.

# Color

### Forground color
We can specify the color of text inside
an element using this property.
We can specify any color in CSS in one of three ways:
1. rgb values : express colors in terms of how much red, green and blue are used to make it up.

![rgb values](https://i.pinimg.com/originals/22/dd/64/22dd6419f9773617a80e3c763a79db2f.png)

2. hex codes : six-digit codes that represent the amount of red, green and blue in a color.

![hex values](https://i.pinimg.com/736x/6e/9d/ca/6e9dcada75a3f3413baa573e97ea4c25.jpg)

3. color names :There are 147 predefined color
names that are recognized by browsers.

![color names](https://i.pinimg.com/originals/70/80/c9/7080c9a6cb3d116f59e5184f8c2101b2.png
)
### Background color

CSS treats each HTML element as if it appears in a box, and the background-color property sets the color of the background for that box.
Many browsers have a white background as a default color .

### Color picker

Every color in a computer screen is created by mixing amounts of red,green, and blue. To find the color we want, we can use a color picker.

 ![color picker](https://openjfx.io/javadoc/13/javafx.controls/javafx/scene/control/doc-files/ColorPicker.png)


4. HUE :Hue is near to the colloquial idea of color.
5. Saturation :refers to the amount of gray in a color.
6. Brightness :refers to how much black is in a color.

### Contrast

When picking foreground and background colors, it is important to ensure that there is enough contrast for the text to be legible:
1. low contrast.
2. medium contrast.
3. high contrast.


The high contrast is better than the low one.

![contrast](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcTer1lu5B5GNDjeEHGiYpMeaOTIW9_X5TReUg&usqp=CAU)

### Opacity
Allows us to specify the opacity of an element
and any of its child elements.

![opacity](https://community.adobe.com/legacyfs/online/1775293_opecity.png)

The **HSL** & **HSLA** values to specify colors.

# Text

### Typeface Terminology

1. **SERIF**:used for long passages of text because they were considered *easier to read*.
2. **SANS-SERIF**:if the text is small sans-serif fonts can be *clearer to read*.
3. **MONOSPACE**:they align nicely, making the text *easier to follow*.

![textType](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcTl-S5z_1kJhMx3F5JQg67iVgDliznE5CfSQg&usqp=CAU)

Properities that affects the fonts :
1. **weight** : *adds emphasis* and affect the amount of *white space* and *contrast* on a page.

2. **style** : Italic fonts, Oblique font styles 
, normal font style.

3. ***stretch*** : In narrow versions of the font, letters are thinner and closer together.
In expanded versions they are thicker and further apart.

![font properties](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ntg5f.png)

### Typeface

![typeface](https://miro.medium.com/max/3840/1*ScX40gMiAltFAxs_AhcXWw.jpeg)

#### How to choose the typeface ?
Typefaces are subject to copyright, so the
techniques you can choose from are limited by their respective licenses:

1. **font family** : specify the typeface that should be used for any text inside the element(s) to which a CSS rule applies.

2.**font size** : specify a size for the font, there are many ways to specify the size :
* pixels
* percentages
* ems

![units of type size](https://user.oc-static.com/upload/2018/04/30/15251064835155_fontsizes.png)
Programs such as Word, Photoshop and InDesign offer the same sizes of text, because they are set according to a scale or ratio.

![scale](https://i.pinimg.com/originals/dc/f2/b0/dcf2b00c9588b2f3bde7ef169867fafc.jpg)

3. **font face** : allows us to use a font, even if it is not installed on the computer of our browsing.

4. **font weight** :allows us to create bold text, it can take two values :
* normal
* **bold**

5. **font style** : it can take three values :
* italic
* oblique
* normal

### Uppercase & lowercase
#### Text transform
It contains three values :
* uppercase : the text appear uppercase ,like this : **FONT**.

* lowercase : the text appear lowercase, like this : **font**.

* capitalize :the first letter of each word appears capitalized,like this : **Font**.

### Underline and strike
#### Text decoration
Specify these values :
* none
* underline
* overline
* line through
* blink

### Leading
#### line height
It's measured from the bottom of the descender on one line to the top of the ascender on the next.

![leading](data:image/png;base64,)

### Alignment
#### text alighn
Allows us to control the alignment of
text, it can take one of four values:
* left
* right
* center
* justify

### Vertical Alignment
It's commonly used with inline elements such as `img`,`em`, or `strong` elements, and it takes these values :
* baseline
* sub
* super
* top
* text-top
* middle
* bottom
* text-bottom

### Indenting Text
Allows us to indent the first line of text within an element, it can be specified using pixels or ems.

### Drop Shadow
It used to create a drop shadow, which is a dark version of the word just behind it and slightly offset.

### Styling Links
Browsers tend to show links in blue with an underline by default,the links maybe visited or not visited:
1. :link : allows us to set styles for links that have not yet been visited.

2. :visited : allows us to set styles for
links that have been clicked on.

### Responding to Users

Allow us to change the appearance of elements when we are interacting with them, it takes these values :
* :hover :it's applied when we hovers over an element with a pointing device such as a mouse.

* :active :it's applied when a button is being
pressed or a link being clicked.

* :focus :it's applied when an element has focus.

### Attribute Selectors
Allow us to create rules that apply to elements that have an attribute with a specific value.

 ![selectors](https://cf.ppt-online.org/files/slide/k/Kbp3XcismqFREgGuz9OBIWY1vDx6MwHVeZQjC5/slide-9.jpg)
